channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Donald Trump’s Remarks Rattle NATO Allies and Stoke Debate on Cost Sharing
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, in Cleveland on Wednesday. In an interview, he suggested that he would use a country’s level of military spending as a factor in deciding whether the United States would honor its commitment to defend NATO allies.
item.description: The candidate’s contention that he might not defend allies that do not pay enough of the costs raised alarms across a continent unsettled by Russia and rising populism.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Attacker in Nice Plotted for Months and Had Accomplices, French Prosecutor Says
item.media:description: The Paris prosecutor, François Molins, who handles terrorism investigations in France, at a news conference on Thursday where he gave an update on the Nice attack case.
item.description: There was no evidence that Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people on Bastille Day, had direct contact with the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Erdogan Sends a Text Across Turkey, Urging Loyalty
item.media:description: A pro-government demonstration in Ankara, Turkey, on Wednesday. Turkish officials on Thursday moved to assure the public that the state of emergency would not lead to the widespread curtailment of individual freedoms, and that the government would focus on targeting suspected coup plotters.
item.description: As a post-coup-attempt purge by the government intensified, Turkish officials assured citizens that the state of emergency would not trample on personal freedoms.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Brazil Arrests 10 in Terror Plot as Olympics Near, Officials Say
item.media:description: Brazilian marines performed a drill at Flamengo Beach, near the site that will host the sailing competitions of the 2016 Olympic Games.
item.description: The arrests were announced at a time when the Brazilian authorities are coming under scrutiny over security preparations for the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Abroad in America: Behind a Facade of G.O.P. Unity, Frayed Edges Painfully Exposed
item.media:description: Attendees at Quicken Loans Arena on Wednesday, the third night of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: A Times foreign correspondent is deciphering the action at the Republican convention for a global audience.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: North Korea Revives Coded Spy Broadcasts After 16-Year Silence
item.media:description: Kim Dong-sik, a former intelligence officer for North Korea, in Seoul, South Korea, in 2013. He said a cryptic series of numbers on North Korean radio resembled coded messages he used to listen to when he was a spy.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Mysterious numbers aired by a North Korean radio station last month and again last Friday have puzzled South Korean intelligence officials and analysts.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Beijing Journal: Unearthing China’s Past at a Market Whose Raffish Air Is a Selling Point
item.media:description: A dealer of Mao-era propaganda and antiques in his shop on the second floor of the Exhibition Hall at Panjiayuan, Beijing’s biggest antique and flea market.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Collectors of rare books and posters find gems in Panjiayuan’s ramshackle alleyways, or make discoveries in its more exclusive little shops.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Sinosphere: China Investigating Data Leak and Swindling of H.I.V. Patients
item.media:description: An H.I.V.-positive patient at a hospital in Beijing. A recent leak of medical records of H.I.V. carriers in China has prompted calls for greater security.
item.description: People with H.I.V. across China report receiving calls from people with access to their medical information, and some say they were asked to send money.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Veterans Group in Zimbabwe Denounces Robert Mugabe
item.media:description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, center, at the burial of Charles Utete, a former chief secretary to the president and cabinet, in Harare on Tuesday.
item.description: The organization, which represents veterans of Zimbabwe’s independence war, has traditionally been a pillar of support for Mr. Mugabe.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Zimbabwe National Liberation War Veterans Association

item.title: Sentence for Oscar Pistorius Challenged by South African Prosecutors
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at the High Court in Pretoria, South Africa, this month.
item.description: The six-year sentence that the sprinter received for the murder of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, was “shockingly too lenient,” prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Israeli Defense Minister Compares Beloved Palestinian Poet to Hitler
item.media:description: A memorial for the Palestinian poet Mahmoud Darwish in the West Bank city of Ramallah in 2008. He occupies a unique place among Palestinians: their national poet, beloved by politicians, academics and defiant youth.
item.description: Avigdor Lieberman, an ultranationalist, said that Army Radio should not have aired a show about Mahmoud Darwish, who is considered the Palestinians’ national poet.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Letter From Europe: Fast Footwork as ‘Events’ Intrude on British Politics
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May’s recent acknowledgement of a Russian threat contrasts with her previous, more malleable stance on President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.description: After unsettling developments at home and abroad, a fresh slate of leaders is staking out new positions in a time of not-so-nimble reinvention.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Envisioning Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy: The U.S. Steps Back
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump with his family at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Trump’s unconventional proposals on NATO, troop deployment, trade and intervention would most likely reduce engagement with other nations, with potentially risky results.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Second Possible Zika Infection Is Found in Florida
item.description: If the two cases are confirmed, they would be the first transmissions in the continental United States.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Mexican Journalist Who Exposed Scandal Says Lawsuit Is Meant as a Warning
item.media:description: The journalist Carmen Aristegui in Mexico City on Thursday. “The idea is that we are harassed, intimidated, that we self-censor ourselves,” she said of the lawsuit.
item.description: The broadcaster who helped break news that President Enrique Peña Nieto’s wife had secretly bought a luxury home says she is being sued by her former boss.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: F.C.C. Backs Swedish Company to Run American Phone Routing System
item.description: Major wireless carriers pushed for Telcordia because of the cost savings, but some intelligence officials have raised national security concerns.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LICHTBLAU

item.title: Sewage Spill, Check. Rerouted Race, Check. Contracting the Zika Virus ...
item.media:description: Insurance policies worth $2 billion have been taken out at the Rio Olympics for terrorist attacks, natural disasters and “unknown peril.” But claims about Zika virus may not be covered.
item.description: Insurance companies for the Rio Olympics are already serving notice that they may not cover every type of loss related to Zika.
item.dc:creator: KEN BELSON

item.title: Secrecy Reigns as U.N. Seeks a New Secretary General
item.media:description: António Guterres in Geneva in 2014, when he was the United Nations high commissioner for refugees. Mr. Guterres was one of the top vote recipients in a secret Security Council straw poll for the secretary general’s job.
item.description: Diplomats emerged from the nearly two-hour voting session with lips sealed about whom they had given a thumb’s up or thumb’s down to.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The Interpreter: Donald Trump’s Ambivalence on the Baltics Is More Important Than It Seems
item.media:description: A Latvian infantry unit during a NATO exercise in the forest of the Adazi military base in Latvia last year.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: In an interview Wednesday, Mr. Trump suggested breaking a NATO obligation that is central to upholding the postwar peace in Europe and the balance of power with Russia.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Exxon Mobil Acquires InterOil for $2.5 Billion
item.description: InterOil’s holdings in Papua New Guinea are a potential source for liquefied natural gas.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Edward Snowden to Help Develop a Safer Phone for Journalists
item.media:description: Edward Snowden, who spoke via a video connection from Russia, said he was working with a computer hacker to see if it would be possible to modify a smartphone to alert journalists working in dangerous environments to electronic surveillance.
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Snowden, speaking from Russia to an M.I.T. Media Lab conference, said the idea was to alert users to electronic surveillance in dangerous areas.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF

item.title: Ukraine’s Security Services and Rebels Are Said to Be Equals in Torture
item.description: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International cites abuses by both sides in the war, including waterboarding and the use of electric shocks.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Group Backed by U.S. Gives ISIS 48 Hours to Leave Syrian City
item.media:description: A soldier from the United States-supported Syria Democratic Forces in the city of Manbij this month.
item.description: The ultimatum comes after reports that dozens of civilians were killed this week near the city of Manbij in airstrikes by the United States-led coalition.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MARCUS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Macedonia’s Political Parties Reach Deal to End Crisis
item.description: The deal clears the way for early elections in the tiny Balkan nation, which has been consumed by a wiretapping scandal.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: Viking Ship Sailing the Great Lakes Is Getting Conquered by U.S. Regulations
item.media:description: The oak-hulled Draken was built using a patchwork of clues from archaeological finds, boatbuilding traditions and Norse legends.
item.media:credit: Jacob Hamilton/The Times-MLive.com, via Associated Press
item.description: The Draken Harald Harfagre made it from Norway to the Great Lakes, where it was told that it would have hire a pilot to continue through.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Leave London After ‘Brexit’? Steve Cohen Doubles Down
item.media:description: A family office that manages Steven Cohen’s $11 billion fortune has doubled the size of its work force in London.
item.description: The billionaire investor is expanding the London office of his firm, Point72 Asset Management, even as other firms pare back.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: Heroin and Pill Overdoses Claim Immigrant Victims, Catching Families Off Guard
item.media:description: Awad Elsayed Elmatbagi, the director of an Islamic funeral home in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, with his son, Kareem. They have buried several young men in the last two years who are thought to have died from heroin overdoses.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Parents from Russia and the Middle East are often unfamiliar with the signs of drug abuse and may not know how to navigate the world of treatment and recovery.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ROBBINS

item.title: Pilgrimage: A 21st-Century Journey to Mecca and Medina
item.media:description: An image of Mecca from the virtual reality film, “Pilgrimage.”
item.media:credit: Luca Locatelli/Institute, for The New York Times
item.description: The Times has produced a virtual reality film from Islam’s holy cities, directed by the photographer Luca Locatelli.

item.title: Man, on Fire, Tries to Drive Car Into Australian Police Station Garage
item.media:description: A bomb disposal expert and other emergency service personnel gathered outside the police station in Merrylands, a suburb of Sydney, Australia, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Sam Mooy/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: The driver, who is in serious condition and has not been identified, was stopped after running his car into a steel door in the Sydney suburb of Merrylands.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: E.C.B. Keeps Rates Steady, but Still Faces Plenty of Uncertainty
item.media:description: The exit to a subway station near the Bank of England in London.
item.description: The eurozone is dealing with aftershocks of earlier crises, while coping with more recent threats like Britain’s vote to leave the European Union and a shaky banking system in Italy.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Sports Court Upholds Ban on Russian Track and Field Athletes
item.media:description: Yelena Isinbayeva of Russia at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Track and field’s global governing body had barred Russia’s team from competing in Rio de Janeiro because of an elaborate cheating plot.
item.description: A ruling on Thursday said the sport’s governing body had the authority to bar Russians for doping.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: Transcript: Donald Trump on NATO, Turkey’s Coup Attempt and the World
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump greeting supporters in Cleveland on Wednesday.
item.description: The Republican presidential nominee discussed his views on foreign policy with David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman of The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: Why Libraries Are Everywhere in the Czech Republic
item.media:description: The library at the Strahov monastery in Prague.
item.media:credit: Pavel Horejsi for The New York Times
item.description: The country has a public library for every 1,971 people — 10 times the U.S. rate — and a population that still borrows and reads printed books.
item.dc:creator: HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: What in the World: That Green Square (or Circle) in Mexico City Might Save Your Life
item.description: Symbols painted on the sidewalks of the earthquake-prone city mark the places to gather when the tremors start.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: What in the World: Business Owners Turn to an Unlikely Mascot: Hitler
item.description: The Nazi dictator’s image has been used to sell fried chicken, shampoo and jeans in places as varied as India and the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The West’s Crisis of Leadership
item.media:description: The French police patrolling at Place de la République in Paris after the Nov. 13 attacks. Today, France and the United States are probably the West’s two main targets of Islamist terrorism.
item.description: Through 18 awful months, the French have proved remarkably resilient. More so than their officials.
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Jihad and the French Exception
item.description: France is no more Islamophobic than its neighbors. It’s just more frontal in the way it handles Islam in the public sphere.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD KHOSROKHAVAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Living With Death in Baghdad
item.description: Iraqis have grown far too accustomed to a life of terrorism and corruption.
item.dc:creator: SINAN ANTOON

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
